citations.narrative:
* Rusted, jagged metal was observed along the bottom of three metal enclosure gates. Nine dogs are in contact with the
affected enclosure gates located in sheltered housing. The surfaces were rough in appearance. Rust can erode and
deteriorate all metal surfaces to the point that the metal surfaces can no longer be readily cleaned and sanitized.
Excessive rust affects the structural integrity of all metal surfaces. The licensee must ensure that this and all other
surfaces are free of rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitation or affects the structural strength of the surface.
Correct by 4/21/23.

* One outside metal wall located on the west side of the main kennel has an area of missing metal that is exposing
jagged, sharp edges. Three dogs are in contact with the affected area located on the outdoor runs attached to sheltered
housing. The metal was turned inwards towards the dogs. Jagged edges with sharp points could cause potential injury.
The licensee must ensure all surfaces are free of any jagged edges or sharp points that might injure the animals. Correct
by 4/4/23.

* An estimated 1/2 inch gap in the cement flooring was observed in the office / whelping room housing two dogs.
Accumulations of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards can collect in the gap area creating
unsanitary conditions. In addition, the affected area cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized. The licensee must fill all
gaps with a material that will allow the cement surfaces to be readily cleaned and sanitized on a routine basis. Correct by
4/21/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.1(c)(1)(i) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
*   Rusted, jagged metal was observed along the bottom of three metal enclosure gates.  Nine dogs are in contact with the 
affected enclosure gates located in sheltered housing.   The surfaces were rough in appearance.  Rust can erode and 
deteriorate all metal surfaces to the point that the metal surfaces can no longer be readily cleaned and sanitized.  
Excessive rust affects the structural integrity of all metal surfaces.  The licensee must ensure that this and all other 
surfaces are free of rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitation or affects the structural strength of the surface.   
Correct by 4/21/23. 
3.1(c)(1)(ii) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
*   One outside metal wall located on the west side of the main kennel has an area of missing metal that is exposing 
jagged, sharp edges.  Three dogs are in contact with the affected area located on the outdoor runs attached to sheltered 
housing.  The metal was turned inwards towards the dogs.  Jagged edges with sharp points could cause potential injury.  
The licensee must ensure all surfaces are free of any jagged edges or sharp points that might injure the animals.  Correct 
by 4/4/23. 
3.1(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general.

*  An estimated 1/2 inch gap in the cement flooring was observed in the office / whelping room housing two dogs.  
Accumulations of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards can collect in the gap area creating 
unsanitary conditions.   In addition, the affected area cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized.   The licensee must fill all 
gaps with a material that will allow the cement surfaces to be readily cleaned and sanitized on a routine basis.  Correct by 
4/21/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
